;当他咯咯笑的乘客从后面遮住眼睛时，一名年轻的科威特人戏剧性地摇动车把司机在一条狭窄车道的拐弯处猛冲着摩托车，对一辆轻便摩托车冲向他带来的潜在危险感到高兴。

;

;现在是泰国芭堤雅晚上 9 点，夜间表演才刚刚开始。

;< p>;“他们就这样一圈又一圈地转，直到凌晨 3 点或 4 点，”女按摩师艾米说道。 “他们不是坏人，他们没有喝醉——我不认为他们吸食大麻，”艾米补充道，只透露了一个名字。 “但他们还是婴儿。他们一定是喝了太多母乳了。”

;

;就在她说话的时候，另一支自行车车队在她的按摩店旁流下了眼泪，每辆自行车上都挤着三名乘客：科威特男孩赛车手意见不一，这对他们来说是一种滋扰。芭堤雅这座城市长期以来一直欢迎世界各地的游客，但似乎有点不确定如何应对友善而热闹的骑自行车的新客人。

;

;他们的铅笔胡须，甚至更细的胳膊和腿，都证明了这群夏季新移民的年轻和缺乏经验。

;

;当地人说，他们大多数年龄在 18 至 21 岁之间，自 7 月以来已有数千人来到这里。为了躲避科威特的酷暑，他们将留在泰国，直到九月初新的大学学期开始。

;

;当然，芭堤雅也很热，但不像科威特那么热，那里的水银可以推动超过 50 摄氏度（122 华氏度）。

;

;在泰国芭堤雅的冰箱中发现一具外国人肢解尸体

;

;科威特学生多年来一直来到芭堤雅，但去年大流行后边境重新开放后，他们的人数激增。

;

;在社交媒体和年轻人对骑车回家的热爱的推动下，对摩托车的迷恋也有所增长。

;

;每晚警察在学生居住的芭堤雅街道上进行拦截，但未能改变科威特游客的风险分析。事故数量也没有增加——本月一名游客在一次车祸中差点失去一条腿。

;

;7 月 14 日至 8 月 15 日期间，警察向科威特骑手开出 800 张超速罚单，扣押了 272 辆自行车，并罚款 153 辆。芭堤雅交警在一份声明中表示，自行车店老板向无照的人出租车辆。

;

;游客都是年轻人，按照泰国的标准，他们都很富有，他们几乎无一例外都想骑这辆自行车。夏天的必备配件——轻便摩托车或摩托车，通常不戴头盔。

;

;他们的滑稽动作被社交媒体渲染得更加精彩。

;

;“每个人都在家里通过 Snapchat 观看比赛，” 21 岁的苏丹是科威特市的一名技术学院学生。 “是的，这有点危险，但我们不在乎。现在家里的每个人都想来这里。”

;

;

;

;芭堤雅是泰国最有风险的度假胜地，以无拘无束的夜生活而闻名，这也是吸引数百万游客的原因之一每年。

;

;但是科威特的穆斯林人群并不是来酒吧或夜总会的。相反，他们在 Soi Yen Sabai 周围预订了酒店，这是一条狭窄的小巷，遍布阿拉伯餐馆和咖啡馆、旅行社和自行车租赁店，其娱乐活动大部分是自制的。

;

;在地下通道附近的宽阔道路周围，这是对危险、即兴且高度非法的摩托车街头比赛的最大胆尝试。

;

;与《亚洲本周》分享的视频显示，在入口处设立检查站后，学生们排着长队被警察拘留。前往他们扎营的道路。

;

;其他图像显示，失去控制的骑手所受的伤害越来越严重。据报道，科威特骑自行车的人在与泰国人的车辆刮擦或碰撞后也发生过几次打斗。

;

;但令当地人感到震惊的不仅仅是自行车比赛，因为社交媒体鼓励游客突破可接受的界限。

;

;上周分享的一段隐藏摄像头视频据称显示一名持枪男子在俯瞰芭堤雅的热门家庭观景点搜查一群科威特男子。

;

;该视频结果是一群科威特学生使用假武器恶作剧 - 为国内日益增长的社交媒体受众提供的内容。

;

;尽管如此，距离新大学学期开始还有一周，几乎没有迹象表明

;

;“我们来这里是因为科威特现在太热了，食物很好，酒店也很便宜，”21 岁的工科学生奥马尔·阿里 (Omar Ali) 说道来自科威特技术学院。 “这对我们来说非常好......我们的钱在这里很充裕。”

;

;芭堤雅灵活的旅游业很乐意帮助他们消费，感谢淡季的到来，收入仍在从长期的恢复中恢复，全球大流行的艰难岁月。

;

;“我会说足够多的阿拉伯语，可以拿走他们的钱，”街上一位要求匿名的摩托车租赁店老板开玩笑说。 “我不明白为什么人们会抱怨这些孩子，因为他们是唯一给我们带来生意的人……现在是淡季，如果没有这些孩子，生意就会非常冷淡。”

;

;泰国旅游局他们对新市场始终保持警惕，因为他们的目标是今年接待 2500 万人次入境游客，但仍比疫情爆发前的高峰期少 40%。

;

;印度人、马来西亚人和香港人纷纷回流。俄罗斯人仍然是常客，特别是当人们试图避免被征召入伍参加入侵乌克兰的战斗时，而中国仍然是游客数量最多的国家——尽管与新冠疫情爆发前相比有所下降。

;

;据中国官方媒体报道，8 月第一周，有 95,581 名来自中国的游客抵达泰国，比 1 月至 8 月初的 1,589 万人次游客增加了数量，为泰国经济注入了数十亿美元。

;

;旅游业占泰国经济的比重专家表示，一旦算上间接支出，该支出将占该国经济的 12% 至 20%。

;

;泰国央行行长 Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput 于 8 月 16 日表示，尽管存在地缘政治不确定性和国内经济陷入僵局，但泰国经济正在复苏政治。

;

;泰国已在看守政府统治下三个多月了，因为在 5 月份的民意调查中获得最多席位的选举获胜的前进党已被阻止组建新政府。

;

; >;

;“整体经济正在消费和旅游业的推动下复苏，”Sethaput 表示，并补充说，在旅游业的帮助下，第一季度经济同比增长了 2.7%。

;

;今年在两国结束长期外交争端后，沙特阿拉伯成为新的游客来源国，向游客和大手笔投资者敞开了泰国的大门。

;

;其他中东游客 - 包括科威特人——泰国在他们的地图上出现的时间更长，因为泰国是一个相对凉爽的避难所，可以躲避国内炎热的夏季气温。它也是顶级的医疗旅游地点，产业价值超过 10 亿美元。

;

;回到 Soi Yen Sabai，奥马尔·阿里 (Omar Ali) 露出令人放松的笑容，消除了对被捕或受伤的担忧。

;< h3>;“我想尝试一下”：泰国大麻对亚洲游客的吸引力;

;他一边走向轻便摩托车，一边不停地抽烟，而一位朋友的脚踝因前一天尾气烧伤而缠着绷带，一瘸一拐速度跟上。

;

;他们是一对快乐的学生，他们的青春似乎为他们披上了盔甲，以应对即将到来的夜晚骑行的风险。

;

;“这是最好的假期。我们所有的朋友都在这里，我们有自由，明年我们肯定会回来。”他说。

;周六，在加拿大西部与野火作战的消防队员得到了增援和温和天气的帮助。美国有记录以来最严重的火灾季节，建筑物被毁，浓烟弥漫在空气中，并促使数万名居民下令疏散。

;

;火焰被扑灭在距离黄刀镇 15 公里（9 英里）的海湾内。西北地区首府，疲惫的消防队员在不列颠哥伦比亚省基洛纳周围得到了喘息的机会。但消防队员距离宣布胜利还差得很远，特别是在未来几天天气预报将更加干燥和多风的情况下。

;

;“我们还没有脱离险境，”野火信息负责人迈克·韦斯特维克 (Mike Westwick) 说道。黄刀镇的官员。 “我们的形势仍然严峻。返回并不安全。”

;

;官员称，自周三晚间发布疏散令后，该市 20,000 名居民中的大多数开始逃离，黄刀实际上已成为一座鬼城。长长的车队堵塞了主要高速公路好几天，那些无法上路的人排队等待紧急航班离开城市。官员称，最后 39 名医院病人已于周五晚上乘坐加拿大军队的飞机运出。

;

;周六，官员们表示，目前通往黄刀镇的唯一道路是安全的。大约 2,600 人留下来，包括应急小组、消防员、公用事业工人和警察，以及一些拒绝离开的居民。

;

;夏洛特·莫里特 (Charlotte Morritt) 是周四离开的人之一，她因难以忍受的情况而做出了这一决定她担心这种烟雾对她 4 个月大的儿子不健康。

;

;原住民电视网的记者莫里特 (Morritt) 和她的儿子乘坐疏散航班向西约 1,500 公里（950 英里）抵达育空地区怀特霍斯的安全，而她的伴侣留下来监视他们的财产并帮助建立防火带和扑灭火灾。

;

;“我们知道这只是时间问题，”一直关注媒体的莫里特说即将来临的野火的更新和卫星图像。

;

;“太可怕了”：随着加拿大火灾烟雾向南飘移，纽约的空气质量是世界上最差的

;

;空中加油机投放了水和阻燃剂，以保持黄刀镇的火焰。挖了一条 10 公里（6 英里）长的消防线，消防队员部署了 20 公里（12 英里）长的软管和大量水泵。

;

;加拿大今年的野火数量创历史新高，在美国部分地区造成令人窒息的烟雾。据加拿大跨机构森林消防中心称，总共发生了 5,700 多起火灾，从加拿大一端到另一端，燃烧面积超过 137,000 平方公里（53,000 平方英里）。

;

;全部周六，不列颠哥伦比亚省进入紧急状态。省长大卫·伊比 (David Eby) 宣布，已命令约 35,000 人撤离全省野火地区，另有 30,000 人处于疏散警报之下，这意味着他们应该做好离开的准备。

;

;伊比 (Eby) 周六告诉记者，目前的情况情况“严峻”，并警告“情况变化很快。”

;

;他表示，他正在限制前往受火灾影响地区的非必要旅行，以便为流离失所的居民腾出酒店、汽车旅馆和露营地等住宿设施伊恩·斯图尔特 (Ian Stewart) 和他的妻子周五做出了“令人焦虑”的决定，带着他们 4 岁的边境牧羊犬撤离基洛纳，驱车 335 公里（210 英里）前往不列颠哥伦比亚省克利尔沃特镇.

;

;“烟雾确实令人窒息，大块的灰烬落得到处都是，”他周六说道。他们收拾了几个手提箱、护照、笔记本电脑和狗粮，在拥挤的车流中驾车逃跑。

;

;周六，一股风将烟尘从不列颠哥伦比亚省带入了西雅图地区。美国国家气象局气象学家达斯汀·盖伊说。当烟雾到达时，普吉特海湾地区刚刚从创纪录的高温中恢复过来。盖伊说，周六晚上到周一的空气质量可能会达到不健康的水平。

;

;加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多于周五会见了一些南下前往艾伯塔省埃德蒙顿的黄刀镇撤离人员，并在 X 上分享了这一消息。 ，前身为 Twitter 的社交媒体平台：“我们支持你。”

;

;特鲁多赞扬了今年应对火灾和其他自然灾害的消防员、警察、军事人员、红十字会和其他人员。夏季。

;

;“损失惨重，极端天气事件增多。在整个过程中，我们看到加拿大人挺身而出，”他在埃德蒙顿告诉记者。

;Shein 是南非 Google Play 商店中下载次数最多的购物应用。而且它甚至没有那么努力。

;

;这家总部位于新加坡的快时尚品牌在 Covid-19 大流行期间在非洲大陆脚下的国家推出，并通过口碑和渠道进行扩张。提供首次购买者折扣。它已经引起了如此大的轰动，以至于当地零售商感到震惊，监管机构正在调查该公司在向购物者发送包裹时是否利用了进口税漏洞。

;

;约翰内斯堡 24 岁的接待员塔希拉·库马洛 (Taahira Khumalo) 说，她现在她所有的衣服都在网上购买，Shein 是一个她不断回归的品牌，受到其具有竞争力的价格、流行时尚和交货速度的吸引。

;

;“Shein 提供非常好的折扣，而我不喜欢等待我的包裹到达很长时间，”她说。 “自疫情以来，技术进步了，现在我真的不需要离开舒适的家去购物。”

;

;随着 Temu 起诉 Shein，中国快时尚的竞争蔓延到法庭

;

;Shein 成立于中国，正在非洲工业化程度最高的国家的新兴电子商务市场中站稳脚跟，并与美国巨头沃尔玛公司和亚马逊公司展开竞争，后者也想这样做.

;

;

;

;沃尔玛试图以传统方式赢得当地人的青睐，十多年前，沃尔玛以昂贵的代价收购了国内零售集团 Massmart Holdings Ltd.，但迄今为止未能成功。不负众望。自 2004 年以来，亚马逊一直在这个拥有约 6000 万人口的国家提供网络服务，预计未来几个月将在南非推出电子商务配送业务。

;

;随着人口快速增长，但正式的服务却很少。零售，甚至更少的互联网购物，许多零售商知道他们最终必须弄清楚如何让非洲为他们服务 - 而南非是最明显的起点。

;

;“亚马逊和 Shein 将当地零售商 Foschini Group Ltd. 旗下拥有折扣服装连锁店 Jet，其首席执行官安东尼·图恩斯特罗姆 (Anthony Thunström) 表示： “南非采用数字或在线购物的速度非常缓慢，因此我认为竞争是件好事。”

;

;南非的中产阶级不断壮大，该国近四分之三的人口拥有互联网接入，而且越来越多的人居住在与该地区大多数其他国家相比，城市地区更加集中。电子商务约占该国零售业的 4%，这意味着潜在的财富可以赢得。

;

;不过，先发优势并没有真正帮助沃尔玛。当这家美国零售商首次收购销售服装、冰箱、洗衣机和罐头食品的 Massmart 时，它雄心勃勃地在非洲各地开设门店。但落后的基础设施和寻找优质房地产的困难使这一梦想变得黯淡。

;

;相反，在过去三年中，该公司专注于建立南非在线销售，并派出了其电子商务公司之一的西尔维斯特·约翰(Sylvester John)专家们前往约翰内斯堡，目标是将 Massmart 打造成南非顶级的当日配送百货网站。 Massmart 已经在改进其网站，重新设计的重点是确保网站首先针对移动设备而不是桌面设备进行格式化。 John 表示，这是因为南非消费者强烈偏好在移动设备上在线浏览和购物。

;

;去年，Massmart 在线销售的商品价值增长了 90% 以上，达到 23 亿美元兰特（1.2 亿美元），有助于证明沃尔玛收购该部门的决定是合理的，以准备与主要竞争对手亚马逊正面交锋。尽管亚马逊尚未确定在该国推出零售业务的具体日期，但近几个月来，亚马逊一直在为当地招聘广告。这家总部位于西雅图的公司因与土著团体就土地的传统用途发生争议而暂停，并于 6 月获得许可，继续在开普敦附近建设当地总部。

;

;

;

;全球尽管该国的反垄断监管机构正在审查电子商务价格的制定方式，并且该国正在与严重阻碍经济增长的不稳定的电力供应作斗争，但零售商仍大举进军南非。

;

;“非洲已经展示了自己的能力在技​​术方面实现跨越式发展——我们已经在网上银行和移动货币中看到了这一点，我认为我们在使用应用程序进行的购买中也看到了这一点，”约翰内斯堡 Sasfin 证券分析师亚历克·亚伯拉罕 (Alec Abraham) 表示。 “虽然南非经济目前陷入困境，但像这样的大公司涉足这门市场表明了这个市场的潜力。”

;

;

;中国长期以来一直声称，它对有争议的浅滩和其他海域特征的领土主张——基于所谓的历史性权利——使其能够划出直线基线，建立广阔的沿海管辖权。

;在菲律宾方面，一些立法者可能会认为越南” ，东盟内部国家间关系的开展在很大程度上以务实主义为基础，”他补充道。

;

;阿鲁盖表示，虽然南中国海的类似目标可能会超越意识形态差异，更大的问题在于菲律宾和越南是否能够接受各自的主张。

;Children in a park in China have graduated from feeding real monkeys to offering bananas to a human inside a costume of the Monkey King, a character from the classic 16th century novel Journey to the West.

;

;Video clips of the Monkey King character eating food fed by children through a hole in an artificial hill in a park in northern China's Hebei province went viral on August 16.

;

;The man playing the character – who is also widely known as Sun Wukong in Chinese folklore – is surnamed Yu and is a full-time performer.;

;In the video, he is performing a passage from the novel in which Sun Wukong is buried under the Five Elements Mountain for 500 years – a punishment from Buddha after he rebelled against heaven, by squeezing himself into the hole in the hill.

;

;Moved by his predicament, several children offered Yu items such as cookies, potato chips, instant noodles, and most commonly, bananas – which are stereotypically regarded as the favourite food of monkeys.

;

;“I'm starving. So delicious,” Yu tells the children, vividly imitating the tone of the Monkey King character shaped in 1980s Journey to the West television dramas adapted from the novel.

;

;The novel was written by Wu Cheng'en during the Ming dynasty (1368 - 1644) , and is regarded as one of the four great novels in Chinese literature.

;

;The mythical adventure tells of the legendary pilgrimage of the Tang dynasty Buddhist monk Xuanzang, who travelled from the empire's capital Chang An, today's Xian city, to the west, including India and Central Asia to seek the Buddhist sutras.

;

;In the company of three disciples, the Monkey King, the half-human, half-pig Zhu Bajie, and sand orc Sha Wujing, Xuanzang suffers all manner of trials and tribulations on their journey.

;

;The novel has been adapted into an array of television dramas and films in the mainland, Hong Kong and even Japan and South Korea.

;

;A Journey to the West drama made in 1986 was the earliest television adaption of the novel.

;

;In the adaptation, The Monkey King character, played by Peking opera actor Liu Xiao Ling Tong, set the standard for amateur Monkey King performers constantly seen nowadays in Chinese parks and at tourist attractions.

;

;Some performers are notorious for tricking tourists to take photos before forcing them to pay.

;

;Yu, however, said he only played the role to promote the Journey to the West culture.

;

;The former soldier has been playing the role for years, and other than acting in the park, he has also performed other chapters, such as Real and Fake Monkey King, on the street, at commercial events and in live-streams.

;

;“What a nice job, with free food and accommodation,” one online observer said.

;

;“It is rare to see a job which contains so much happiness nowadays,” said another.

;

;“By being fed too much, one day he might be able to play Zhu Bajie,” quipped a third.

;Ever-rising temperatures in Hong Kong have prompted calls for better ventilation in the city's prisons, but activists and lawmakers remained divided over providing inmates air conditioning.

;

;Former Democratic Party lawmaker Emily Lau Wai-hing and opposition activist Raphael Wong Ho-ming urged the Correctional Services Department last week to improve ventilation and cooling arrangements in prisons as Hong Kong would only get hotter with climate change.

;

;Lau also suggested installing air conditioners, an idea shot down by former security chief Lai Tung-kwok, who told the Post: “Prisons don't have air conditioners. That's common sense and our common understanding.”

;

;But Lau, a justice of the peace who visited prisons regularly to check on conditions and collect complaints lodged by inmates, explained her concerns about the heat saying: “This isn't about relaxation, but human rights – the right to live and the right to health.”

;

;She said she did not suggest air conditioning in the past when it was not so hot, but the weather was becoming extremely hot now and some inmates described being damp with perspiration all day.

;

;The Hong Kong Observatory has warned of a “significant long-term increasing trend” in temperatures from August to October. It predicted earlier that this summer could be one of the top 10 hottest summers on record.

;

;Last year, the city had 52 “very hot days”, when the maximum temperature hit 33 degrees Celsius (91.4 Fahrenheit) or higher, the second highest annual total on record. Hong Kong tallied 29 “very hot days” in its first seven months of this year.

;

;In the southern United States, high temperatures and heat-related deaths among prisoners have resulted in family members of inmates and prison advocates calling for air conditioning in jails.

;

;The Texas Tribune reported at least nine prisoner deaths from reported heart attacks or cardiac events in prisons without air conditioning on days when outdoor temperatures exceeded 37.8 degrees from mid-June to mid-July this year. Most of the state's 100 prisons have partial or no air conditioning.

;

;'Life's better in prison': rising cost of living hits Hong Kong's poor hard

;

;Sharon Dolovich, a law professor from the University of California, Los Angeles and director of its prison law and policy programme, told the Post that prison authorities should consider air conditioning to provide a humane correctional environment amid climate change.

;

;She disagreed that providing physical comfort in prisons would reduce the deterrent effect, saying there was no evidence that criminals considered the conditions in jail when committing a crime.

;

;Ultimately, she said, the deprivation of liberty and banishment from society were “a deeply harmful punishment to inflict on anybody”.

;

;There have been no reports of heat-related deaths among Hong Kong prisoners, but Lau and activists who had been jailed and visited inmates in recent years said the city's prison authorities could do more.

;

;They said prisoners had to suffer sweltering heat made worse by old prison buildings with poor ventilation and insufficient cooling measures.

;

;The Correctional Services Department said it had added fans and allowed its officers to buy handheld fans and cooling towels for inmates.

;

;Replying to a letter from Lau, a spokesman for the Correctional Services Department said it had added or replaced 2,300 fans across all 29 correctional facilities since 2020, installed more than 15,000 electric fans and put more than 1,600 roller fans with anti-suicide designs in cells.

;

;It also began retrofitting gates and windows at Stanley Prison in 2018 to improve ventilation, with 300 gates and 1,000 windows replaced so far.

;

;The spokesman said other measures included using heatproof paint for buildings and installing solar panels or plants on roofs where suitable.

;

;Figo Chan Ho-wun, a former convenor of the now-disbanded Civil Human Rights Front who was jailed 22 months for offences related to the city's 2019 social unrest, recalled developing heat rash and waking up in the middle of the night during summer when he was at the Lai Chi Kok Reception Centre.

;

;“The heat rash was on my arms, body, inner thighs, even on my back. It was really tough,” he said. “You couldn't pull yourself together to write letters, you couldn't read, you would sweat just sitting there.”

;

;'Threat' of prison visitors to be investigated: Hong Kong security chief

;

;The conditions were slightly better when he was transferred to Shek Pik Prison and was in a dormitory, not confined in a single-person cell.

;

;He urged authorities to at least consider offering cool water to inmates, as only hot water or tea were available when he was in prison.

;

;Raphael Wong, a former chairman of the League of Social Democrats who was jailed four times for protest-related offences, agreed that the ventilation in dormitories was acceptable.

;

;But he asked prison authorities to improve conditions across institutions and holding areas for inmates. He suggested having shower areas in communal spaces, such as canteens, for inmates to cool down before or after meals.

;

;Two lawmakers rejected Lau and Wong's proposals, saying the prison authorities had already done what they could to improve conditions for prisoners during summer.

;

;Pepper spray used to stop prison fight between 3 Hong Kong inmates

;

;Former security secretary Lai and Gary Chan Hak-kan, who chairs the Legislative Council's security panel, said air conditioning was a luxury not enjoyed by many Hongkongers.

;

;“I have great reservations about installing air conditioning, as resources are precious and after all, inmates are serving sentences inside. They are not there for enjoyment,” Chan said.

;

;As for the suggestion to have more shower areas, Lai said that would strain manpower needed to oversee showers and the resulting damp would be another issue to deal with.

;

;But he was confident the authorities would consider individual requests for more showers.

;China's embassy in Manila did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The Chinese coastguard said on August 7 it had told the Philippines not to send ships to the shoal and not to send “construction materials used for large-scale repair and reinforcement” to the warship.

;The planned resupply mission “is a clear demonstration of our resolve to stand up against threats and coercion, and our commitment in upholding the rule of law”, the armed forces said.

; Sun, 20 Aug 2023 08:20:02 +0800 US imports of car parts with links to Chinese forced labour face legal scrutinyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3231672/us-imports-car-parts-links-chinese-forced-labour-face-legal-scrutiny?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.20 07:27;
;;

;Electric-vehicle batteries and other car parts are the latest products under scrutiny as part of Washington's effort to stamp out US links to forced labour in Chinese supply chains, according to a document.

;

;Until now, enforcement of a year-old US law that bans the import of goods made in Xinjiang, China, has focused mainly on solar panels, tomatoes and cotton clothing. But now, components that may include lithium-ion batteries, tyres and major car raw materials aluminium and steel are increasingly subject to detentions at the border.

;

;Increased inspection of products destined for car assembly plants by US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) could signal difficult times ahead for carmakers who will need solid proof that their supply chains are free of links to a region where the US believes Chinese authorities have established labour camps for Uygurs and other Muslim minority groups.

;

;Beijing denies any abuses.

;

;More than a year of enforcement of the Uygur Forced Labour Prevention Act (UFLPA) has already stymied development of solar energy projects as detained panel shipments languish in US warehouses. Installations of large solar energy facilities for utilities dropped 31 per cent last year due to constrained panel supplies, according to the US Solar Energy Industries Association trade group, which has said conditions have improved somewhat this year.

;

;Biden limits US investments in China tech, makes 'emergency' declaration

;

;Both solar energy and battery-powered electric vehicles are critical industries in the Biden administration's push to wean the US from dependence on fossil fuels and to combat climate change.

;

;When shipments are detained, CBP provides the importer with a list of examples of products from previous reviews and the kind of documentation required to prove they are not made with forced labour, CBP said.

;

;That document, a recent version of which was obtained through a public records request, was updated between April and June of this year to include batteries, tyres, aluminium and steel, a CBP spokesperson said. When the law was beginning to be enforced last year, the agency was primarily focused on the three commodities identified as high priorities in the UFLPA statute: cotton, tomatoes and polysilicon, the raw material used in solar panels.

;

;“The timing of these changes does not reflect any specific changes in strategy or operations”, a CBP spokesperson said in a statement, adding that the list of eight product types was “not exhaustive”.

;

;The agency did not specifically respond to questions about increased scrutiny of automotive imports. It said its focus “is where there are high risks in US supply chains.”

;

;Canada probes Nike, Dynasty Gold over alleged use of forced labour in China

;

;In a report to Congress last month on UFLPA enforcement, CBP listed lithium-ion batteries, tyres, “and other automobile components” among the “potential risk areas” it was monitoring.

;

;The expanded focus is reflected in CBP data, which shows 31 motor and aerospace shipments have been detained under UFLPA since February of this year. Detentions of base metal shipments, which would include aluminium and steel, have also soared from about US$1 million per month at the end of 2022 to more than US$15 million a month.

;

;CBP said it was not able to disclose additional information related to enforcement activities.

;

;Though the car detentions are small compared with the more than US$1billion of solar panel imports that have stalled at the border, they have put the industry on alert, according to lawyers and supply-chain experts.

;

;“It's a very complex supply chain and obviously a detention would be incredibly disruptive to an auto company,” said Dan Solomon, a lawyer with Miller & Chevalier who advises manufacturers on potential forced-labour risks.

;

;In May, Solomon spoke about UFLPA compliance at a private event for car company executives in Detroit. “Without a doubt the manufacturers are focused on it,” he said.

;

;The stepped-up focus on carmakers follows a study by Britain's Sheffield Hallam University published in December that said nearly every major carmaker has exposure to products made with forced labour in Xinjiang.

;

;The report prompted a probe by US Senate Finance Committee Chair Ron Wyden, which his spokesperson said is ongoing.

;

;“It is appropriate for CBP to scrutinise imports in this space,” Wyden said in a statement.

;

;Of 13 carmakers and suppliers contacted, four – Mercedes-Benz USA, Volkswagen, Denso, Continental AG and ZF Friedrichshafen AG – said they had not had products detained under UFLPA.

;

;“Under the UFLPA, we've further increased our due diligence with global media screening, risk analysis and supplier and buyer training on sustainability and human rights,” a Volkswagen spokesperson said in an email.

;

;A Continental spokesperson said by email the company “is committed to human rights and respects and actively fosters those rights.”

;

;Ford, Bosch, General Motors, Honda, Toyota, Stellantis and Magna said in written statements that they were committed to ensuring their supply chains were free of forced labour but did not respond to questions about detainments under UFLPA.

;

;Tesla did not respond to requests for comment.

;

;The chief executive of Exiger, a provider of supply-chain management software, said the solar detentions are an indication of where auto component enforcement may be headed.

;

;“If you're a car manufacturer and you have not started mapping your supply chains for the critical minerals and the parts of the sub-assemblies that are going through China and where they are getting their goods from, you are running a real peril as we go into the back half of the year,” Exiger CEO Brandon Daniels said.

;British police have questioned Myanmar's ex-ambassador to London, stripped of his post by the military junta after a 2021 coup, over his refusal to leave a diplomatic residence, his lawyer said Saturday.

;

;“On 15 August, my client was interviewed by the police about an allegation that he trespassed on diplomatic premises, namely the ambassadorial residence in which he has lived since he became ambassador to the UK in 2013,” said Neil Swift, lawyer for Kyaw Zwar Minn.

;

;In April 2021, diplomats close to the junta seized the embassy in central London and refused access to Kyaw Zwar Minn, a supporter of Aung San Suu Kyi's civilian government which was overthrown by a coup in February that year.

;

;At the time, the British government indicated that it would offer its protection to the ousted ambassador.

;

;'Coup in London': Myanmar envoy locked out of embassy after break with junta

;

;The British foreign minister at the time, Dominic Raab, condemned “the bullying actions of the Myanmar military regime in London” and paid tribute to Kyaw Zwar Minn for his “courage”.

;

;The former envoy has not left the ambassador's residence since. He has refused to give it back to his country's representatives whose legitimacy he does not recognise.

;

;The official residency “remains the property of the Union of Myanmar, and my client has always maintained that he is more than happy to hand over the keys to a representative of the democratically elected government of Myanmar”, Swift said in a statement.

;

;Kyaw Zwar Minn has faced no criminal charges, he said, adding that the British attorney general would first have to decide “whether there is sufficient evidence of any offence at all”.

;

;Neither the British foreign office nor the police responded to requests for comment.

;

;The 2021 coup plunged Myanmar into a conflict that has displaced more than a million people, according to the United Nations, with thousands more arrested.

;

;Myanmar's relations with the United Kingdom, the former colonial power, have deteriorated sharply since the military seized power.

; Sun, 20 Aug 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Why China is still on the sidelines in Afghanistan, 2 years after messy US troop pull-outhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3231577/why-china-still-sidelines-afghanistan-2-years-after-messy-us-troop-pull-out?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.20 06:00;
;;

;The withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan in the summer of 2021 continues to be seen as a “black mark” on Joe Biden's presidency – a chaotic and deadly exit that left the war-torn country in a security vacuum as the Taliban swiftly advanced on Kabul.

;

;Two years on, Afghans are still struggling under one of the world's worst humanitarian crises, with most international aid, including from the United States, suspended following the Taliban takeover.

;

;But no major power, not even neighbouring China, appears keen to fill the void that Washington left after its nearly 20-year troop deployment sparked by the September 11 terror attacks.

;

;Afghanistan's severe food insecurity, bleak security and economic situation, and the Taliban's repressive policies against women and girls indicate that the strategic fallout from the messy end to the US military presence could be felt for many years to come, pundits said.

;

;Despite being widely criticised over the US and Nato pull-out, Biden had remained defiant, defending the end of the “longest war in American history” as an “extraordinary success”, and claiming the Afghan exit would help the US focus its energies on the strategic rivalry with China.

;

;“There's nothing China or Russia would rather have, would want more in this competition than the United States to be bogged down another decade in Afghanistan,” Biden said on August 31, 2021, in a statement marking the end of the evacuation operation.

;

;China has made no secret of its joy at America's Afghan debacle and what it calls the failure of US hegemony. It repeated those sentiments on Tuesday – the two-year anniversary of the Taliban takeover of Kabul.

;

;Washington had yet to learn “profound lessons” from the “Kabul moment” of its botched withdrawal, Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said.

;

;“The event left behind profound lessons which, to this day, are still worth deep thought,” he said.

;

;“What happened in Afghanistan marked a military, political and counterterrorism failure of the US, and once again proved that military intervention, political infiltration and 'democratic transformation' from the outside will not work and will only breed turmoil and disaster.”

;

;In an apparent jab at the Biden administration, Wang added: “Over the past two years, a certain country has cut off aid, frozen Afghanistan's assets and imposed sanctions, worsening the suffering of the Afghan people.”

;

;Washington has hit back at such characterisation. A Pentagon report last year accused Beijing of trying to “erode US and partner influence” in Afghanistan by highlighting the withdrawal as “evidence that the US is an unreliable partner and declining power”.

;

;However, a US State Department review released last month was deeply critical of the way the evacuation was handled, saying decisions made by Biden and his predecessor Donald Trump had “had serious consequences for the viability” and security of the former US-backed Afghan government.

;

;The Biden administration has played down the criticism, insisting it learned lessons that were later applied in managing the Russian invasion of Ukraine and other crises.

;

;Jennifer Murtazashvili, a non-resident scholar in the Asia Programme at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the US had suffered “a very serious hit” to its credibility in the region, and it was too early to claim that the lessons from the Afghan exit had been learned.

;

;“The US has not had the time to take stock and learn lessons from Afghanistan,” Murtazashvili said. “This is because the same administration that facilitated the disastrous withdrawal remains in power today.”

;

;'Dark future': Afghanistan's Taliban government marks 2 years in power

;

;Sourabh Gupta, a senior policy specialist with the Institute for China-America Studies in Washington, said the chaotic withdrawal was a black mark on the Biden presidency.

;

;“The chaotic images of desperate Afghans fleeing alongside the US military transport plane at Kabul airport will linger in the collective memory, much like images of the helicopter evacuation from the rooftop of the US embassy in Saigon in 1975,” Gupta said.

;

;But he questioned the claims about a lasting negative impact on American credibility and global standing.

;

;“Just as the 'Saigon moment' of 1975 had few long-lasting ramifications for the credibility of US deterrent power and commitment in the Asia-Pacific – let alone beyond the region, so also the 'Kabul moment' will have even fewer reverberations in external theatres beyond Southwest Asia,” Gupta said.

;

;Wang Duanyong, a research fellow at the Shanghai International Studies University specialising in China's overseas interests, said the end of the US deployment in Afghanistan represented another failed attempt to promote modernisation and political change.

;

;“Afghanistan's recent history of nearly 300 years has seen many attempts at modernisation by internal and external forces, all of which have ended in failure. While this is a failure of the US and other external forces, it is more a failure of Afghanistan and its people,” he said.

;

;However, it would be a mistake to underestimate the lingering influence of the US, Wang – who has made five lengthy field trips to Afghanistan since 2021 – said.

;

;The US is still the largest donor to Afghanistan and has a strong presence on the ground and, despite the Taliban's much-touted anti-American posturing, the regime had been careful to strike a balance between ties with China and the US, he said.

;

;“The Taliban initially tried to win strong support from China and Russia when it came back to power, trying to break its diplomatic isolation. But after it resigned itself to the reality of not being recognised by the international community, ties with China cooled and the Taliban instead sought to increase contacts with the US, in a show of diplomatic flexibility.”

;

;The humanitarian crisis facing Afghanistan was essentially an economic crisis, Wang said. It had been caused mostly by a prolonged period of lack of development, the Taliban's regressive attitude to women's rights, its over-reliance on overseas assistance and the inability to produce an economic reconstruction plan.

;

;Sadiq Amini, a programme manager at Observer Research Foundation America who oversees external relations and outreach, described the chaos of the US withdrawal and the Taliban's reinstatement as a “collective failure” of Washington and other powers.

;

;“This is partially on the US, majorly on Afghans themselves, but more on the regional countries including China, Russia, Iran, Pakistan and others who needed to care enough, and be capable enough to plan, allocate resources, and support Afghanistan post-US withdrawal,” Amini said.

;

;“As a result of their collective failure, the immediate consequences and threats emanating from Afghanistan today, or in the future, are posed against the countries in the region.”

;

;Then a political assistant at the US embassy in Kabul, Amini had helped coordinate the month-long evacuations two years ago. He voiced concerns about the “highly fragile” political, security, and economic situation in Afghanistan.

;

;Following the Taliban takeover, external powers including the US, China, Pakistan, Iran, Russia and India had only “minimal influence” in Afghanistan, and that too was “tactical, short-term, and transactional in nature”, Amini said.

;

;“It definitely is not serving Afghanistan.”

;

;Amini was particularly critical of China's ties with the Taliban and its cautious, wait-and-see approach in post-war Afghanistan, with a primary focus on countering Islamic extremism and ensuring stability on its western border.

;

;Diplomatic overtures to the Taliban “will not lead to influence”, he said. “Rather, it will lead to resentment against China, which is already showing among the people of Afghanistan, who see China warmly engaging the Taliban with no vision to serve Afghans in the long-term.”

;

;Short of a formal recognition, China was among the first countries to welcome the Taliban's return to power and one of only a handful to host a Taliban charge d'affaires.

;

;Wang Yi, now China's foreign policy chief, became the first foreign minister of any country to meet the new Taliban rulers in Kabul when he travelled there in March last year.

;

;In contrast, Beijing had appeared more cautious in its dealings with the hardline militant group during the Taliban's first takeover in 1996, refusing to recognise it and shutting all crossings along their 92km (57-mile) border.

;

;Amini argued that considering the doubts over the Taliban's willingness or ability to prevent terrorism from spilling over to neighbouring countries, Beijing should reach out to non-Taliban Afghans, the US and regional countries to collectively address the Afghan crisis.

;

;Other observers were less optimistic about China's future role.

;

;Andrew Small, a senior transatlantic fellow with the German Marshall Fund's Indo-Pacific Programme, said Afghanistan in the aftermath of a US withdrawal was always seen as “more of a trap than an opportunity” for China.

;

;“And the Chinese government has been careful not to fall into it,” he said.

;

;“The risk is that deeper involvement looks easy during periods of calm and then turns into a liability when the situation turns and when resentment about foreign presence grows.”

;

;China was under no illusions about great influence over the Taliban, Small said.

;

;“[China] have dealt with them for over two decades, and even if they hoped for a more pragmatic approach in government, they are aware of the Taliban's ideological nature,” he said. “There is modest scope for expanding their commercial footprint in Afghanistan, but only at a level that doesn't turn into significant risks or liabilities.”

;

;Small also said China's ties with the US over Afghanistan did not have “the depth of cooperation that was there in the past”. But the two sides still had relatively similar objectives there, so “it isn't likely to be a major area of Sino-US contention either.”

;

;China and the US used to cooperate during the 2010s on various capacity-building initiatives in Afghanistan, including police training and demining activities.

;

;Yun Sun, China programme director and co-director of the East Asia programme at the Stimson Centre in Washington, Afghanistan was no longer the centre of geopolitical sparring.

;

;For Beijing, the situation there is not as bad as might have been expected two years ago, Sun said, though “at this point, Afghanistan is still more a challenge than an opportunity for China”.

;

;“The large exodus of refugees or inflow of militants into China did not happen. No major power has shown any interest in filling the vacuum in Afghanistan,” she said. “China is not willing to take on such a big burden and risk by itself, which is why it has organised a regional multilateral platform- the Foreign Ministers' Meeting of Afghanistan's Neighbours- to develop a collective approach.”

;

;Murtazashvili also said the Afghanistan factor was unlikely to figure in the US-China relationship going forward, despite a shared interest in rooting out terrorism.

;

;China had become a much more significant target for terrorists in Afghanistan than American interests, she said. “The US left Afghanistan with its tail between its legs, humiliated. China seems to be the next great power with interests in Afghanistan – so it has become a target for opponents of the Taliban.”

;

;Chinese investments in Afghanistan have been targeted by Islamic State-affiliates and other terror outfits. At least five Chinese nationals were seriously injured in December when an Isis affiliate attacked a hotel in downtown Kabul catering to Chinese businesspeople.

;

;Murtazashvili said while the Taliban had on the one hand failed to ensure the promised internal security and stability, the regime's reticence over Beijing's suppression of its ethnic minority Uygur population in exchange for economic support had also backfired.

;

;“The treatment of the Uygurs has been a quiet rallying call for groups like Islamic State who are able to point out what they believe to be the hypocrisy of the Taliban who seem to have quite close relations with the Chinese government regardless.”

;

;Wang at the Shanghai International Studies University also said that China's biggest problem in Afghanistan was a lack of security guarantees.

;

;Beijing and its embassy in Kabul have repeatedly warned of the risks of investing in Afghanistan at this stage.

;

;“With Afghan trade accounting for only about one ten-thousandth of China's foreign trade, Afghanistan is of limited significance for China, especially economically,” he said.
